text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Those are the seminal vessels. (Pause 10 seconds) Family Member: And this, we were just surprised because there’s nothing that would indicate all that. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: His PSA being low, and the prostate not being enlarged, and the preliminary report they told us we thought when you called down that day we were here. Doctor: I know. I’m really upset by passing incorrect information to you based on the verbal report. That’s the danger of doing that. Family Member: Mm, hmm. I’m like what were you looking at? The other sixteen lymph nodes first? (Laughs) Patient: We’re hoping you got the samples switched or something like that. Doctor: You know I was actually gonna check that and I haven’t done that. The big question is did anybody else have prostate surgery on the same day. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Mm, hmm. Doctor: Not by me, but it could be another doctor. Family Member: I would like to check it just for peace of mind only, but there’s nothing that would lead us to think it was all this and to be fifty to sixty percent involved with the prostate kind of blew our minds a little bit. Doctor: Me too. Yeah.

text: Patient: Well I mean is there a benefit to taking the pain medication? Doctor: Yeah, you’d be more functional. Patient: Well I’m functionable. Family Member: But you’re in pain. Patient: Well then I also feel that if I’m masking the pain too much, then I’m overextending myself. Or maybe I shouldn’t be. Doctor: Oh well, set your activity level and don’t exceed it. Patient: Then I don’t need pain medication. Family Member: Yeah, but you can’t walk around in the stores; you can’t walk around for any length of time. If we go to Florida in February, you have to be able to walk on the beach; you aren’t going to be able to - Patient: But then again, if I’m taking pain medication to hide that pain, is that a good idea because then I’m gonna overextend myself. Doctor: I am so not going to get in the middle of this discussion with you two. You know the answer. If you need to go somewhere and be functional, go take your medication. You’re just chillaxing in front of the television, you’re probably just fine. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I’m sure you over-did it. I should have gone by your house and taken that darned ladder. I didn’t.

text: Patient: It’ll go back someday. Doctor: Mm. Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: Anywho! Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, here's where we are. Your PSA is six something- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -and it was two something before. So with that rise, I got a little worried. Because I don't want the Xtandi to get away from us. At that point, there was a study and there still is, where people on Xtandi if they start to do this with their PSA, might be eligible to add another pill right on to that. So you still stay on Xtandi. But this other pill might make the Xtandi sort of work better. And, you know, if you were on full dose, you'd be eligible, if you were on three pills, as well as just the two pills a day is still an option. So initially, we weren't sure if it was going to open because this was a study that had a sugar pill arm that I wasn't too keen on. But with this new, kind of like update, everybody gets the pill. So this is where the study is. So here you are in your Xtandi. Xtandi, Xtandi, Xtandi. And then you get randomized. So flip of a coin to either get this new medicine at a certain dose, or this new medicine at the same dose. Okay, so so far, both arms are the same, you just get a new medicine at the same dose, okay, no placebo. This arm is going to keep you like that, so you take the Xtandi plus the new pill at the new dose, no problem, you're just on that. This arm is you on Xtandi plus the new pill, but every month, they're going to try to increase that dose gently. So you get another pill that has more milligrams in it. While that's happening, if you were on this arm, you get a matching placebo. So you do get a sugar pill, but that's in addition to the new pill already being on board. You still with me? Patient: No, you gotta slow down. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to say it again? Patient: Try me again. Doctor: Okay, no worries. Okay, here's you. Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: So we know still it’s invisible somewhere, so we can target what we can see. And we can still deal with you know what we can’t see. If that’s the combination of your thinking in terms of correct or that is a possibility? Doctor: I’m thinking that in terms of the sequence if you get the radiotherapy first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That does not close the door to getting hormone therapy down the line. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You start with the hormone therapy, the other option is going to disappear very quickly. And a radiation oncologist is not going to know what to target. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It would be very different if the spot was in the bone. Bone metastasis takes a very long time to disappear. Sometimes you know a small one can take up to a year to disappear. So oftentimes when a cancer is involved, when they start the hormone therapy about three months later, a week later, two weeks later you talk to the radiation oncologist and by the time he starts the radiation planning which might be six to eight weeks later, the spot is still where he can see it, he can zap it and target that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And with a lymph node, uh if we start the hormone therapy even like a couple of weeks before that thing’s going to disappear; he won’t know what he’s targeting. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So all I’m saying is in theory that-

text: Patient: Well, will they tell you, uh, if I went down there and spent a couple of days and had the testing done-. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Will they tell you, uh, if it’s needed? Would they tell if it’s needed or not in lieu of that? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Because I can ask. They won’t show me the films, but they have a special radiologist read it, and they come back to me and tell me if you are likely to go on the study or not. Because if your cancer doesn’t have that antigen, it’s pointless to go on the medication. Patient: Right. It can’t- Doctor: So then we wouldn’t move forward with the treatment. text: Patient: So that, that was well worth being there just for that. Doctor: Oh, I’m so glad. Patient: So I’m well aware of that. Doctor: Awesome. Patient: I told my kids that. I said, oh man, that’s, yeah, so I understand that. Doctor: Yeah, so you know it’s something we consider but just so you know we don’t combine the two, right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t combine Zytiga and the radium together. I specifically say that because there have been patients who have had leftover pills and yeah. Hey, the things going up after I try the pill. But actually, when they combined it people did worse so that study has already been done and people got more bone fractures so that’s no fun. So, I just tell everybody, you know, you’ve had it before. You can go on it after but not at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s actually an absolute no-go black box. Okay, good. Family Member: What does the PSA going up, what does it, is it gonna cause it to spread? Doctor: It might really. No. But it might, again it’s not a reflection of what’s happening. It’s almost like oh, the ship’s sinking and the rats are all kind of jumping off. I’ve had patients that go from twenty to one hundred to five hundred and you’re like, oh, but they actually feel better. So, like it doesn’t match you.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
